statement.tex: %text Find the equation of the plane passing through the point $(-1,3,2)$ and perpendicular to each of the planes $x+2y+3z=5$ and $3x+3y+z=0$. %

step.context: %text If $ax+by+cz+d=0$ is perpendicular to $x+2y+3z=5$ and $3x+3y+z=0$, is the following true? %
step.reason: %text If two planes $a_1x+b_1y+c_1z+d_1=0$ and $a_2x+b_2y+c_2z+d_2=0$ are perpendicular, their normals are also perpendicular and their direction ratios bear the following relationship. % \qquad a_1a_2+b_1b_2+c_1c_2=0

step.context: %text If a point $P(-1,3,2)$ lies on a plane $ax+by+cz+d=0$, what can we say about $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d$? %
step.reason: %text Since the point $(-1,3,2)$ lies on the plane $ax+by+cz+d=0$, it must satisfy the equation of the plane $\therefore -a+3b+2c+d=0$. %

step.context: \text{If }\begin{align} &a+2b+3c=0 \\ &3a+3b+c=0 \\ &a-3b-2c-d=0 \end{align} \\ %text What is the actual equation of the plane $ax+by+cz+d=0$? %
step.reason: \begin{align} &a+2b+3c=0 \quad (1) \\ &3a+3b+c=0 \quad (2) \\ &a-3b-2c-d=0 \quad (3) \end{align} \\ %text Solving $(1)$ and $(2)$ pairwise for $a$, $b$ and $c$. we get, ${\bf a:b:c=7:-8:3}$. Let the actual values be $a=7k$, $b=-8k$, $c=3k$, $d=mk$ (for some $k$). Substituting these in $(3)$, % \begin{align} &1(7k)-3(-8k)-2(3k)-m(k)=0 \\ &7+24-6-m=0 \implies m=25 \end{align} \\ %text Therefore, final equation for the plane, % {\bf 7x-8y+3z+25=0}
